extractions.description: This paper introduces the concept of Green Federated Learning (Green FL), focusing on optimizing Federated Learning (FL) parameters to minimize carbon emissions. It provides a data-driven evaluation of carbon emission profiles in FL tasks and offers guidelines for reducing the carbon footprint while maintaining competitive performance and training time.

type.justification: The paper involves empirical observations and measurements from real-world FL tasks to evaluate and optimize carbon emissions.
type.quote: Our empirical approach quantifies carbon emissions by directly profiling a real-world at-scale FL task.

name.justification: The paper extensively discusses Federated Learning (FL) and proposes optimizations to make FL more carbon-efficient.
name.quote: Federated Learning (FL) — a collaborative machine learning technique for training a centralized model using data of decentralized entities — can also be resource-intensive and have a significant carbon footprint, particularly when deployed at scale.

name.justification: The paper's primary focus is on minimizing the environmental impact of AI by reducing carbon emissions in FL tasks.
name.quote: Green AI is a novel and important research area where carbon footprint is regarded as an evaluation criterion for AI, alongside accuracy, convergence speed, and other metrics.

name.justification: FedAvg is a standard baseline implementation used for synchronous Federated Learning as discussed in the paper.
name.quote: For synchronous FL, the baseline implementation is FedAvg.

is_contributed.justification: FedAvg is used as a standard baseline and is not a contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: For synchronous FL, the baseline implementation is FedAvg.

is_executed.justification: FedAvg is executed in the experiments as part of the asynchronous FL baselines.
is_executed.quote: Regarding energy and carbon footprint, Aggregators and Selectors are responsible for the majority of processing and heavy lifting.

is_compared.justification: FedAvg is compared with other models like FedBuff in terms of carbon emissions.
is_compared.quote: We can see that synchronous FL has a smaller carbon footprint compared to asynchronous FL.
